SciShow, I expect better from you than this misinformation-riddled video. Lots to unpack here:

-"Nuclear comes with massive problems" Actually, it is one of the safest energy sources we have in terms of deaths per unit of energy produced [1].

-"One good thing is, it produces few greenhouse gases." It produces basically none, less than wind or solar [1].

-Thorium's abundance in nature is a red herring. There is no shortage of uranium or plutonium, and in any case "abundance in nature" does not mean that there are lots of thorium deposits that we can conveniently mine [2].

-"While nuclear power today uses uranium as its fuel." Incorrect; nuclear power today uses uranium and plutonium, and a thorium reactor actually uses an isotope of uranium as its fuel, as well as at least some conventional uranium or plutonium to get it started [2].

-"Nuclear Materials that can self-sustain like this are called fissionable." This is incorrect. They are called fissile. "Fissionable" means they can be fissioned by a neutron. "Fissile" means they can sustain a chain reaction [3].

-"T-232 isn't fissionable." Thorium's atomic symbol is "Th," not "T" and Th-232 absolutely is fissionable, it just isn't fissile [3,4].

-"When T-232 is hit by a neutron, it turns into T-233, and that's fissionable." Even if I accept your incorrect definition of "fissionable" and your incorrect atomic symbol for thorium, this statement is false. Adding a neutron to Th-232 turns it into Th-233, but Th-233 then decays into U-233, which is fissile (what you wrongly call "fissionable") [2].

-The implication that thorium's ability to breed fuel makes it different from standard nuclear fuel is wrong. Uranium-plutonium reactors can also breed their own fuels while also fissioning away their high-actinide waste in a fast breeder reactor [2]. Idaho National Laboratories demonstrated this in the EBR-II reactor back in the 1980s[5].

-The distinct issue with high-actinide waste is not its toxicity, but its radioactivity. Solar photovoltaic plants produce a lot more toxic waste than nuclear plants, but it's chemically toxic, not radioactive, so it will also be around in thousands of years.

-"Most uranium in nature is in a nearly-unusable form called U-238." U-238 is fertile, just like Th-232 is, so it's just as useful as Th-232 in nuclear applications [2]. More so, in fact, since we actually do breed U-238 into Pu-239 fuel in far greater quantities than we breed Th-232 into U-233. U-238 is also handy as a high-density material in non-nuclear applications.

-"Enriching the uranium is hard." True, but it's also not required. See heavy water reactor designs like the CANDU [6].

-"The upshot is that thorium can be dug up and put in a reactor with a lot less effort than uranium, once you have the right kind of reactor." *This is not true; we can use natural uranium as a fuel in several reactor designs right now; thorium is no more easy to put into a reactor than uranium [2].

-"Every major nuclear power disaster has been due to a cooling failure." This is incorrect. Chernobyl was caused by a runaway supercritical chain reaction, loss-of-cooling [7]. So was the SL-1 accident in Idaho [8].

-"if [water cooling] fails, you can get a meltdown, like what happened at Fukushima or Chernobyl." Chernobyl was a runaway supercritical chain reaction. There was plenty of cooling water flowing through it right before it blew.

This video presents passive cooling as if it were exclusive to the thorium MSR concept. It's not. [2,5].

-"Since Uranium was much more useful for making nuclear bombs..." That's not why we researched uranium and plutonium as nuclear fuels first. We used uranium and plutonium first because uranium-235 is the only naturally-occurring fissile isotope [9]. By the way, you can absolutely make bombs from Thorium, too, and the U.S. did exactly that [10].

-"...Like the betamax vs VHS fight" would only be a good metaphor if betamax could not exist without having VHS around first. Without already having plenty of fissile nuclear fuel from U-235, you can't do anything with thorium. Nuclear reactors could never exist without U-235.

Please, SciShow, do your homework or at least talk to a competent nuclear engineer. Thorium offers two key intrinsic advantages: it can be bred with thermal neutrons, and when bred into U-233 and fissioned, it produces less high-actinide waste. On the downside, they require more shielding, and there's a lot less experience and knowledge about them because they've never existed outside some experimental test-beds.

Disclaimer: I'm actually for thorium, but it's important to discern the relevant facts from the hype, and all this video is likely to do is muddy the waters even further.

Liquid fuel MSRs can use either thorium or uranium. Thorium MSRs work best with a thermal spectrum (slower neutrons) reactor where fuel is dissolved in a fluoride salt. Uranium MSRs work best with a fast spectrum reactor where fuel is dissolved in a chloride salt.

Both are possible, but the uranium-based MSR is actually easier to build because thorium reactors need to isolate for about 27 days the fertile thorium that absorbs a neutron and turns in protactinium (22 minutes). Otherwise, the protactinium may absorb another neutron and will not transmute into the desired fissionable u-233. This need for a chemical "kidney" to isolate protactinium for 27 days significantly complicates the reactor design. Still doable, just a new and difficult problem to solve.
The u-238 to plutonium-239 transmutation also involves neutron capture, but the decay into the desired pu-239 only take 2.3 days vs the 27 days for th-232 to u-233 decay, so uranium fast MSRs can afford to skip the more complicated chemical separation and isolation of the neutron activated fertile fuel.
Again, both are doable, one is just easier to implement (for now).

First of all, the abbreviation for thorium is Th, not T.

Thirdly, "fissionable" is not what you need to support a chain reaction. That only means the atom splits. You need it to emit at least two neutrons with the splitting - such a material is termed "fissile". U-235 is fissile with slow neutrons. U-238 is fissionable with high-energy neutrons - it splits but won't sustain a chain reaction.

Fourthly, it makes its own fuel only by converting Th-232. This has been the goal of fast breeder reactors since Nixon pushed them in the sixties, only to be shut down by Carter as proliferative. Saying "it makes its own fuel" is misleading - it uses up Th-232, converting it into U-233, just as uranium breeders convert U-238 into Pu-239. The disadvantage of SNF burning reactors is that they have to either be built exclusively at the sites of SNF storage depots or the SNF has to be transported cross country, which is a problematic situation. Nevertheless, replacing all existing PWRs with SNF burning MSRs using the SNF stored at these sites could be an excellent starting point. SNF burning MSRs could be equipped with thorium blankets or cooled with thorium salt, which could produce U233 for a second generation of MSRs that would burn thorium. This U233 could be used to build remote reactors, possibly even nuclear powered railroad engines.

The second type of first generation MSRs would be uranium burning MSRs. These would be fast neutron spectrum MSRs that would breed plutonium from U238, but could burn all of their own long term nuclear waste. As with SNF burning MSRs, they could breed U233 for second generation MSRs in thorium breeding blankets and/or thorium salt coolant.

To a large extent, thorium reactors would have to be second generation reactors. Using Uranium and/or SNF in a thorium reactor poisons he reaction, making it impossible to build a thermal neutron spectrum thorium breeder reactor that burns SNF as well. Because the Nuclear Regulatory Agency requires that thorium be denatured with U235/U238 to insure no weapons grade U233 is produced, all thorium breeder reactors would have to be built using neutrons in the fast neutron spectrum, and in this neutron spectrum the uranium/plutonium cycle is more efficient.

Thorium burners will be desirable for deployment in nations lacking uranium resources and stockpiles of SNF and potentially for mobile power, such as nuclear powered railroad engines, but the immediate focus should e on SNF burning MSRs.
